instructions.instruction: Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.5 Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui,org.eclipse.core.runtime,tudresden.ocl20.interpreter,tudresden.ocl20.logging,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.modelbus,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.pivotmodel,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.essentialocl,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.essentialocl.standardlibrary,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.standardlibrary.java,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.modelbus.ui Manifest-Version: 1.0 Bundle-Activator: tudresden.ocl20.interpreter.ui.InterpreterUIPlugin Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 Bundle-SymbolicName: tudresden.ocl20.interpreter.ui;singleton:=true Bundle-ActivationPolicy: lazy Bundle-Name: Ui Plug-in Bundle-Vendor: TU Dresden, Software Technology Group

Bundle-Name: Simple UML Example Plug-in Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 Bundle-SymbolicName: tudresden.ocl20.pivot.examples.simple Manifest-Version: 1.0 Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 Bundle-Vendor: TU Dresden Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.5
uninstallBundle(bundle:${artifact})
setStartLevel(startLevel:4);
installBundle(bundle:${artifact})

Bundle-Vendor: TU Dresden, Software Technology Group Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 Bundle-Activator: tudresden.ocl20.pivot.essentialocl.StandardLibraryPlugin Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.5 Bundle-Name: OCL Standard Library Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.core.runtime Manifest-Version: 1.0 Bundle-SymbolicName: tudresden.ocl20.pivot.essentialocl.standardlibrary Bundle-Version: 1.0.0 Eclipse-LazyStart: true Export-Package: tudresden.ocl20.pivot.essentialocl,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.essentialocl.standardlibrary,tudresden.ocl20.pivot.essentialocl.standardlibrary.base

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: Dresden OCL2 for Eclipse currently supports the Ecore and UML2 meta-model that are based on the Ecore meta-meta-model. The MDR repository integration is no longer supported, but can be found at https://dresden-ocl.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/dresden-ocl/branches/legacy/ <mdrrepository | metamodels.mof | metamodels.uml>.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: The OCL2 Interpreter has been developed by Ronny Brandt and can be used to interpret already imported OCL2 constraints. Invariants, pre- and postconditions can be interpreted. Initial and let expressions, definitions and body expressions can be used to enrich and prepare the OCL2 interpretation.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.name
property.value: Dresden OCL2 for Eclipse Parser Feature

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: The OCL2 Parser has been developed by Nils Thieme and can be used to open text files and parse them as OCL2 constraints. The constraints parsed by the parser are added to the model in the toolkit on which they have been defined.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: OCL2Java is a code generator developed by Claas Wilke which can be used to generated Java code for imported OCL2 constraints. The code generator uses the aspect-oriented language AspectJ to instrument the generated code into the provided Java code for the imported model used for the code generation. The code generator supports the generation of code for invariants, pre- and postconditions, definitions, initial and defined values, body and let expressions.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: Dresden OCL2 for Eclipse currently supports the Ecore and UML2 meta-model that are based on the Ecore meta-meta-model. The MDR repository integration is no longer supported, but can be found at https://dresden-ocl.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/dresden-ocl/branches/legacy/ <mdrrepository | metamodels.mof | metamodels.uml>.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: This feature includes the core plug-ins of the Dresden OCL2 for Eclipse toolkit. These are the Pivot Model, Essential OCL, the Model Bus and the Standard Library for Java. Additionally, the Apache Commons Lang and the logging plug-in of the toolkit are included.

property.value: Dresden OCL2 for Eclipse Parser Feature

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: The OCL2 Parser has been developed by Nils Thieme and can be used to open text files and parse them as OCL2 constraints. The constraints parsed by the parser are added to the model in the toolkit on which they have been defined.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: This feature includes the core plug-ins of the Dresden OCL2 for Eclipse toolkit. These are the Pivot Model, Essential OCL, the Model Bus and the Standard Library for Java. Additionally, the Apache Commons Lang and the logging plug-in of the toolkit are included.

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: OCL2Java is a code generator developed by Claas Wilke which can be used to generated Java code for imported OCL2 constraints. The code generator uses the aspect-oriented language AspectJ to instrument the generated code into the provided Java code for the imported model used for the code generation. The code generator supports the generation of code for invariants, pre- and postconditions, definitions, initial and defined values, body and let expressions.

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: The OCL2 Interpreter has been developed by Ronny Brandt and can be used to interpret already imported OCL2 constraints. Invariants, pre- and postconditions can be interpreted. Initial and let expressions, definitions and body expressions can be used to enrich and prepare the OCL2 interpretation.
